items.synopsis: A combination of old-fashioned espionage and high-tech surveillance was meant to keep Israelis safe. But when Hamas smashed through the fence, all the systems seemed to fail.

title.children: Paragliders, kidnappings and rockets: How did Hamas pull off such an audacious attack?

image.altText: Fire and smoke rise following an Israeli airstrike, in Gaza City.

items.synopsis: As the death toll from Hamas attacks on Israel and counterstrikes in Gaza climbs, Israel officially declares war and vows to attack Hamas targets.

title.children: Hundreds of bodies recovered from music festival as Israel formally declares war over Hamas attack

image.altText: Two police vans out the tree-lined entrance to a park.

items.synopsis: Emergency services have closed all entrances to the popular spot, located north of the Darwin CBD, with Parks and Wildlife saying it would stay shut "until further notice".

title.children: Woman killed, man seriously injured after tree branch falls at Darwin Botanic Gardens

image.altText: A woman in a 'DISRUPT BURRUP HUB' T-shirt stands in the street with her arms raised

items.synopsis: The battle over the climate is escalating, and nowhere more than in Western Australia, where a new generation of protesters is prepared to break the law to make their point.

title.children: Tilda will remember this day for the rest of her life. It's the day she broke the law

image.altText: A two-image compilation of three women standing together and laughing, with a young woman hugging a humanoid puppet.

items.synopsis: A cruel and incurable disease took former TV personality Fiona MacDonald's voice, and her trademark quick wit and banter with it. But she's not staying silent.

title.children: 'There is no treatment, no cure': Why Fiona MacDonald is making every second count

image.altText: A close up photo of a man in a blue jacket holding a silver whistle

items.synopsis: Institutions that do the wrong thing usually do what they can to cover it up. That’s the force a whistleblower is up against, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: Lost jobs, failed marriages, freedom at risk: Whistleblowers take huge risks at great personal cost

image.altText: A group of men in dark uniforms wearing helmets and holding military-style rifles stand beside an armoured vehicle on a road.

items.synopsis: Israel says it is at war as its soldiers battle Hamas fighters in the streets of southern Israel and launch air strikes on Gaza. Follow live.

title.children: As death toll passes 1,000, Gaza residents tell of ‘unbearable' fear and terror

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Former Israeli intelligence chief Efraim Halevy warned his country had no choice but to respond with full force when it comes to Hamas. Speaking to Radio National this morning, the Israeli intelligence expert and former Mossad chief said his country could not and should not stomach a situation where its citizens were being held hostage. "We've declared war and we have to realise we cannot be choosy in some of the means we have …. to reset the balance between us and them," he said. When asked whether collective punishment by cutting off water and electricity was justified Mr Halevy said there are no rules when it came to terror. He also warned Israel has a lot of means for making things very difficult for Hamas. "We cannot forget they (Hamas) are a terrorist group and in combatting terror you cannot simply go by the book," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former Israeli intelligence chief says you cannot 'go by the book' when combatting terror

children.content: Former Israeli intelligence chief
Efraim Halevy
warned his country had no choice but to respond with full force when it comes to Hamas.

Speaking to Radio National this morning, the Israeli intelligence expert and former Mossad chief said his country could not and should not stomach a situation where its citizens were being held hostage.
"We've declared war and we have to realise we cannot be choosy in some of the means we have …. to reset the balance between us and them," he said.
Former Mossad chief Efraim Halevy.
When asked whether collective punishment by cutting off water and electricity was justified Mr Halevy said there are no rules when it came to terror.
He also warned Israel has a lot of means for making things very difficult for Hamas.
"We cannot forget they (Hamas) are a terrorist group and in combatting terror you cannot simply go by the book," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has condemned the "indiscriminate killing of civilians and citizens". "This is of real concern, but Hamas bear the responsibility for this," he told ABC News Breakfast. "This was a shock attack that was obviously very well planned and I think has shocked the world, the extent of which we haven't seen for 50 years. "Civilians shouldn't be targeted in this and that is what is so horrific about Hamas's indiscriminate actions that took place." He said Australian government agencies were working on a 24-hour basis to ensure the safety of any Australians in the region. "We are concerned as is the whole world, this is a place where citizens of the world do gather," he said. Mr Albanese said Australians could call 1300 555 135 if they are concerned about friends or relatives who were visiting the region. "This is causing a great deal of distress and that is understandable," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM condemns 'indiscriminate killings', says Hamas 'bears responsibility'

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has condemned the "indiscriminate killing of civilians and citizens".
"This is of real concern, but Hamas bear the responsibility for this," he told ABC News Breakfast.
"This was a shock attack that was obviously very well planned and I think has shocked the world, the extent of which we haven't seen for 50 years.
"Civilians shouldn't be targeted in this and that is what is so horrific about Hamas's indiscriminate actions that took place."
Anthony Albanese.
(ABC News)
He said Australian government agencies were working on a 24-hour basis to ensure the safety of any Australians in the region.
"We are concerned as is the whole world, this is a place where citizens of the world do gather," he said.
Mr Albanese said Australians could call
if they are concerned about friends or relatives who were visiting the region.
"This is causing a great deal of distress and that is understandable," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Israeli rescue service Zaka says its paramedics have removed about 260 bodies from a music festival attended by thousands that came under attack by Hamas militants. The total figure is expected to be higher as other paramedic teams were working in the area. Video aired on social media and by Israeli news outlets showed dozens of festival goers running through an open field as gunshots rang out. Many hid in nearby fruit orchards or were gunned down as they fled.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: At least 260 bodies recovered from music festival, Israeli Rescue Service says

children.content: The Israeli rescue service Zaka says its paramedics have removed
about 260 bodies
from a music festival attended by thousands that came under attack by
Hamas
militants.
The total figure is
expected to be higher
as other paramedic teams were working in the area.
Video aired on social media and by Israeli news outlets showed dozens of festival goers running through an open field as gunshots rang out.
Many hid in nearby fruit orchards or were gunned down as they fled.

items.synopsis: Portugal secure a famous Rugby World Cup victory over Fiji, but it was still not enough for the Wallabies to make the quarterfinals. Follow all the action in our live blog.

title.children: Portugal secure famous Rugby World Cup win over Fiji, but Wallabies still knocked out

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wallabies are out of the Rugby World Cup

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: They've done it! Delirium in the stands! Euphoria on the pitch! This is magical! Portugal have deserved this win - they have lit up this Rugby World Cup and have come away as the most impressive of all the lower-ranked nations. The 24-23 victory is not enough for the Wallabies - they are still out of the competition as Fiji earn a losing bonus point. But tonight is all about Portugal.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PORTUGAL SECURE A FAMOUS VICTORY

children.content: They've done it! Delirium in the stands! Euphoria on the pitch!
This is magical!
Portugal have deserved this win - they have lit up this Rugby World Cup and have come away as the most impressive of all the lower-ranked nations.
The 24-23 victory is not enough for the Wallabies - they are still out of the competition as Fiji earn a losing bonus point.
But tonight is all about Portugal.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Brilliant from Portugal! Patience - excellent hands - Portugal have burst through eventually down the left. Raffaele Storti made the break down the blindside and then Rodrigo Marta finished it off! Portugal have a kick to win it! It's from the sideline. Samuel Marques the scrumhalf is lining it up. HE KICKS IT! PORTUGAL LEADS 24-23!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 78' PORTUGAL SCORE A LATE TRY!

children.content: Brilliant from Portugal!
(Getty Images)
Patience - excellent hands - Portugal have burst through eventually down the left.
Raffaele Storti made the break down the blindside and then Rodrigo Marta finished it off!
Portugal have a kick to win it!
It's from the sideline. Samuel Marques the scrumhalf is lining it up.
HE KICKS IT!
(Getty Images)
PORTUGAL LEADS 24-23!
